Award.AwardTitle: The M-STEM Academies at the University of Michigan: An Integrated Approach to Increase the Number and Diversity of Undergraduates in STEM Disciplines

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The M-STEM Academies at the University of Michigan (UM) is providing a holistic support system for cohorts of students with high potential in science that have been traditionally underrepresented or historically not as successful within a highly competitive research university. The effort is based on the nationally recognized Meyerhoff Scholars Program at the University of Maryland Baltimore County and integrates a current pilot program into the natural science and mathematics departments in the liberal arts college at UM. The project provides students a comprehensive bridge program as students transition into UM, including academic coaching, development workshops, and research opportunities.

Intellectual merit: This cross-university effort, rare for an institution of this size, involves collaboration of many academic support units that have a vested interest in success for all students and is laying the groundwork for a long-term institutional transformation at UM. In addition, the proposed evaluation (with a defined control group) contributes to our knowledge of student retention, portability, and scalability of the Meyerhoff model to a range of undergraduates in STEM programs at large research universities.

Broader Impacts: The project represents a well-documented model that is used to increase the number and the academic qualifications of students graduating with STEM degrees. Increasing the number and diversity of students pursuing and completing STEM degrees (with accompanying multicultural competency) also serves to provide a valuable support network for multiple educational communities at UM (and beyond) and provides similar and needed traits to the STEM workforce.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The University of Michigan Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (M-STEM) Academies is an integrated, holistic curricular and co-curricular support system for students with high ability and potential in science who, for reasons of low socioeconomic status, first generation college status, race or gender bias, or lack of rigor of high school background, might not be successful at a highly competitive research university.  Based on the nationally recognized Meyerhoff Scholars Program at the University of Maryland Baltimore County, the M-STEM Academies as funded by the National Science Foundation STEP grant accomplished three significant outcomes.  (1) It integrated two existing small pilot program in two different colleges (the College of Engineering and the College of Literature, Science & the Arts or LSA) into a highly collaborative cross-university effort (NSF funding largely supported the LSA component).  As a consequence, not only did M-STEM become a successful program, but it facilitated other collaborations in STEM education across these traditionally siloed colleges. (2) It greatly expanded the reach of the College of Literature, Science & the Arts program (called MSci) from Biology to include all of the natural science and mathematics departments in the liberal arts college: Astronomy; Biophysics; Chemistry; Earth and Environmental Sciences; Ecology and Evolutionary Biology; Mathematics; Molecular, Cellular, and Development Biology; Physics; and Statistics.  This expansion also increased collaboration among these departments and, as with the collaboration with Engineering, facilitated collaboration in other educational projects.  (3)  It demonstrated that the Meyerhoff Scholars Program model was transportable to a quite different academic setting in a large research-based highly decentralized University. 

At the conclusion of this funding, 287 students have been part of the MSci community consisting of 37% White, 24% African-American, 19% Hispanic, 15% Asian, 2% two or more, and 2% not indicated.  This is considerably more diverse than the College of Literature, Science & the Arts (LSA) in which these students reside, which is 69% White. Between 40% and 60% of the students in any given cohort are likely to come from families with incomes below $50,000.  Only 10% of the students in LSA report the same family income demographics.  Between 30% and 50% of the M-Sci students are first-generation college students compared to about 12% of LSA students.  Lastly, our M-Sci students tend to have lower math ACT scores of around 27 or 28 compared to an average of around 31 in LSA.

Our assessment shows that M-Sci is meeting the goal of the NSF-funded program: to increase the number and diversity of STEM graduates in LSA and ensure they are well prepared to further pursue a STEM career, whether in graduate school, professional school, or directly into the workforce.  Because many students do not declare majors for some time, we define retention, or persistence, in STEM as continuing to take STEM courses.  To isolate the effect of M-Sci participation, we match students based on race/ethnicity, first-gen status, family income, math ACT, and the number of STEM courses their first term (as a proxy for initial commitment to STEM).  M-Sci student are much more likely to stay in STEM than their matched controls throughout their time in school and also persist to a much greater degree even than the general LSA population that starts taking STEM courses.  As a result of this success, the University has committed to continue to support M-Sci for at least the next five years as it continues to seek longer-term funding.
